subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] to tinyallen - about the alice tutorials
msgSnippet: Peter, thank you very much for your effort. Sorry I didn t say this before, but I didn t connect the names. I now consider myself a proficient (if halting)
messageBody:
Peter, thank you very much for your effort. Sorry I didn't say this before, but I didn't connect the names.
   I now consider myself a proficient (if halting) reader and nearly as good a writer. This is only because your completed tutorial got me off my butt to really devote some effort to learning this alphabet I've been interested in so long. Using opportunities my work gives me while I'm being bussed around, I read for an hour or so every workday, and a full hour most weekends. I followed your instructions, figuring that this was a lot of effort to put forth without doing it wrong as well.

   As far as difficult to read for Americans, I have to say my experience might be atypical. With Pittman, Gregg, Unifon and the Simplified Spelling Society, I've been exposed to a lot of different phonetic concepts and might be just a little more open-minded (or -eyed) about ways of presenting speech.
   One valuable thing I came away from was the realization that I don't have quite a complete Awl-On-Ah merger after all. Sounding out your words (in a version of Australian that you wouldn't recognize, but sounds to me like the guy in the Foster's commercial) led me to realize that I could distinguish between On and the other two. I'm still trying to find out just how well my vocabulary is separated, but I've got the concept now - I can't keep myself from hearing it. I'm still trying to decide if I have an Awl/Ah distinction or not. A byproduct of all this was that I became so phonemically aware that I had a bit of difficulty hearing the sense of people talking around me, for a couple of days when I was reading the last two chapters. I had to ask people to repeat themselves a few times; I'm just happy I didn't have to talk on the radio that week!

   I have to admit that skipping the Rs seemed like a mistake. I was constantly slowed by this, and had to remind myself any number of times that the Rs were missing. This was a real headache, and I won't do this myself. In earlier discussions, the consensus seemed to be that Read's own speech dropped quite a few Rs, but that he felt the change in the preceding vowel couldn't otherwise be indicated without more vowel signs.

   Despite that one little difficulty, I found your progressive reader an enjoyable way to ease myself into familiarity with this remarkable invention. Thanks again!

   I've thought myself about a project to practice my writing with. Since I will inevitably produce a strong American accent, I've though of using an American author's writing for a reprise of your own work, another progressive reader - perhaps Mark Twain. I would purely welcome the opportunity to put Huck and Jim's accents through the QS wringer!
trElIgyn

----- Original Message ----
Hello Terry,
I'm the author of the 'Alice in Wonderland' tutorials that you have
just finished.  As you know they are based on the general australian
accent and pronunciations.  Since you are american, I'm curious to
know how challenging you found it read them.
Because I designed them for australians to read and learn rapidly, I
deliberately left out the post-vocalic Rs.  Please note that when
you write quikscript you should include all the TO Rs. 

To me it makes sense that everybody learns two QS versions, one that
follows their own accent (well not exactly their own, but rather
they choose a specific dictionary to use) and then one standardised
international version.  I'm waiting to see if this group will settle
on such a standard thats handles sound mergers and the like.

If we do agree on a standard for international spelling then I would
like to follow up the Alice tutorials with a set of tutorials based
on the Lewis Carroll book 'Through the Looking Glass'. These
tutorials would use the first few chapters of the book to transition
from the Australian accent to the standard and the rest of the book
would be reading practice for the standard.

PS: I would like to produce a general american version of the Alice
tutes, but unfortunately I don't have the time nor enough experience
with the american accent and pronunciations.

   Peter, thank you very much for your effort. Sorry I didn't say this before, but I didn't connect the names.
   I now consider myself a proficient (if halting) reader and nearly as good a writer. This is only because your completed tutorial got me off my butt to really devote some effort to learning this alphabet I've been interested in so long. Using opportunities my work gives me while I'm being bussed around, I read for an hour or so every workday, and a full hour most weekends. I followed your instructions, figuring that this was a lot of effort to put forth without doing it wrong as well.

   As far as difficult to read for Americans, I have to say my experience might be atypical. With Pittman, Gregg, Unifon and the Simplified Spelling Society, I've been exposed to a lot of different phonetic concepts and might be just a little more open-minded (or -eyed) about ways of presenting speech.
   One valuable thing I came away from was the realization that I don't have quite a complete Awl-On-Ah merger after all. Sounding out your words (in a version of Australian that you wouldn't recognize, but sounds to me like the guy in the Foster's commercial) led me to realize that I could distinguish between On and the other two. I'm still trying to find out just how well my vocabulary is separated, but I've got the concept now - I can't keep myself from hearing it. I'm still trying to decide if I have an Awl/Ah distinction or not. A byproduct of all this was that I became so phonemically aware that I had a bit of difficulty hearing the sense of people talking around me, for a couple of days when I was reading the last two chapters. I had to ask people to repeat themselves a few times; I'm just happy I didn't have to talk on the radio that week!

   I have to admit that skipping the Rs seemed like a mistake. I was constantly slowed by this, and had to remind myself any number of times that the Rs were missing. This was a real headache, and I won't do this myself. In earlier discussions, the consensus seemed to be that Read's own speech dropped quite a few Rs, but that he felt the change in the preceding vowel couldn't otherwise be indicated without more vowel signs.

   Despite that one little difficulty, I found your progressive reader an enjoyable way to ease myself into familiarity with this remarkable invention. Thanks again! 

   I've thought myself about a project to practice my writing with. Since I will inevitably produce a strong American accent, I've though of using an American author's writing for a reprise of your own work, another progressive reader - perhaps Mark Twain. I would purely welcome the opportunity to put Huck and Jim's accents through the QS wringer!
trElIgyn
